Office Address:   13 University Place, 627  New York, New York (US) 10003   Email:     ludovic.cortade@nyu.edu     Phone:   (212) 992-7993   Fax:   (212) 995-4187       Bio   In my research, I analyze how films both constitute a symbol of modernity and present us with resurgences of collective beliefs that pre-existed the invention of the cinema. I investigate how mass audiences embrace films on the basis of myths and sensibilities that may revive or adjust ancient narratives to modern times. Literature, aesthetics, history, geography and sociology are key in my attempt to excavate these resurgences. I have written on the relationships between film and literature, theory, space, and politics. My current research focuses on how French film theorists and critics laid the foundation for a sociological approach to film prior to the advent of political modernism. Permission of the instructor required to enroll :       « Teaching  French Cinema » course      or  background in Cinema Studies recommended.             Goal  of the course :       The relationships  between French cinema and politics are twofold : cinema is not only the  mirror image of the political situation in France. It has also been seen as a  key factor in political change. The goal of the course is to analyze the  representation of the political backdrop in French cinema and the shaping of a  collective political consciousness through film in France from the 1930s to the  election of Nicolas Sarkozy. The emphasis is placed on film analysis, the  review of the historical context and the theoritical debates gravitating around  film form and ideology.           The following periods and themes will be discussed :            - The social struggles of the 1930s : the cinema of the  Popular Front ;      - The cinema of Occupation and the impact of the Vichy  ideology on filmmaking (1940-44) ;      - The Cold War, decolonization, filmmaking and film  criticism in the 1950s;      - May 1968, Political modernism and the diverging paths of  the New Wave ;      - Post-modernism and the dusk of the « cinéma  engagé » in the 1980s;      - The revival of politics in the 1990s – 2000s: social  struggle and national identity in the context of globalization.            An  emphasis will be placed on the following films and directors :            Jean Vigo : A propos de Nice (1930)      René Clair : Liberty for us (1931)      Jean Renoir : The Crime of Mr. Lange (1936)      Jean Renoir : Liberty for us (1936)      André Malraux and Boris Peskine: Man’s Hope (1938)      Claude Chabrol : The Eye of Vichy (1993)      Alain Resnais and Chris Marker : Statues Also Die (1953)      Alain Resnais : Night and Fog (1955)      Jacques Willemont : La reprise du travail aux usines Wonder (1968)       Jean-Luc Godard and Jean-Pierre Gorin : Tout va bien (1972)      Georges Pérec : Un homme qui dort (1974)      Jean-Jacques Beineix : Diva (1981)      Jean-Pierre Dardenne and Luc Dardenne : The Promise (1996)      Robert Guédiguian : Marius  and Jeannette (1997)      Robert Guédiguian : The  Last Mitterrand (2005)      Laurent Cantet : Human  Ressources (1999)      Jean-Pierre Jeunet : Amélie (2001)      Nicolas Phillibert : To Be and to Have (2002)      Raymond Depardon : 10th Court District (2004)            EVALUATION :    3 written clip analysis                                         NYU Department of French                              19 University Place, 6th Floor                        New York, NY 10003                 Contact Us | © New York University , Arts and Science
